comments.text:
As a lifelong Seahawks fan and someone who always watches closely, I can 
tell you w/o a doubt that "Sherm" is probably one of the most misunderstood 
figures in the NFL.  He's got heart, intelligence, football savvy, and is a 
charitable, kind person off the field.  Yes, he talks trash, but he leaves 
it all on the field every week,  & he backs it up too.  He's totally 
legit.  If he played for your team, you couldn't help but like him- trust 
me.

top_comment.text:
Editor’s note: This comment first posted on 12/19/13, which has nothing to 
do with QB Russell Wilson (b. 11/29/88) in this video moving through the 
cafeteria at the NFL Seattle Seahawks training facility with 12:19 PM shown 
on a digital clock with a red LED display. Also unrelated is Wilson 
eclipsing 2007 HEisMAN Trophy winning QB Timothy Richard Tebow (b. 8/14/87 
in the Philippines) in NFL starts during the 2013 season despite Tebow’s 
1st start coming on 12/19/10—exactly three years before this comment was 
composed. In his first start, Tebow and his Denver Broncos suffered a 23-39 
loss at Al Davis' OAKland Raiders. Tebow is unrelated to actor Kenneth 
Franklin, who played Newell College Knights football star (with NFL 
prospects) Tim Pardo in the “Offense” ep. of Dick Wolf’s NBC drama “Law & 
Order: Criminal Intent”, which aired 11/29/07—Russell Wilson’s 19th 
birthday and nine days before Tebow won the HEisMAN. In the football/sexual 
assault-themed ep., a teammate calls the Tim Pardo character “Timbo” 
outside Tim’s parents’ Grand View Hall apartment building. Pardo is a 
suspect in the murder of TRACi kWON (Yin Chang) who lived in another 
building where the lady in  #309 answered the intercom's buzz 
indiscriminately, allowing just about anyone in the building—something DA 
Investigator Gates (Cortez Nance Jr.)notes as he slips both hands in his 
pants pockets. Franklin played Johnny Kerns in the “Dreams Deferred” ep. 
(12/5/12) of Wolf’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit”.Jay Berwanger won 
the first HEisMAN in 1935, finishing ahead of finalists Monk Meyer (Army, 
Jr.); William Shakespeare (Notre Dame, Sr.); Pepper Constable (Princeton, 
Sr.). 

Russell Wilson—then the Wisconsin Badgers QB—placed 9th in voting for the 
77th HEisMAN in 2011, which Baylor QB Robert Griffith III won. Oregon RB 
LaMichael James placed 10th for the 77th HEisMAN and faced Wilson's Badgers 
in the 98th Rose Bowl the following month; Wilson's older brother, Harrison 
Wilson IV, turned six on 7/12/89—the day the 8th place finisher for the 
77th HEisMAN, Boise State QB Kellen Moore, was born. For the 77th HEisMAN, 
Andrew Luck finished 2nd; Trent Richardson 3rd; Montee Ball, 4th; tyRANN 
MAtTHieu 5th. James got a big break in the 2010 season when he replaced 
Oregon Ducks teammate LeGarrette Blount (b. 12/5/86 in Madison,FL) in the 
lineup after Blount punched Boise State DE BYron hOUT (b. 8/15/90 in Coeur 
d' Alene, ID) immediately after a 19-8 season opening loss to hOUT's Boise 
State Broncos. Blount then hit teammate Garrett Embry, who was attempting 
to restrain him.

Franklin played Adrian Scott in the charity football game themed “But 
There’s a Catch” ep. of USA Network drama “Royal Pains”; it aired 7/6/11 on 
George Walker Bush’s 65th b’day. Both Wilson and Tebow are “faith on their 
sleeves”, self-professed Christians. Wilson attended the private, $17,000 
per year K-12 Collegiate School in Richmond,VA, while Tebow was home 
schooled in the Jacksonville, FL area, but allowed to play football for the 
Panthers of public Allen D. Nease High (10550 RAY Road, Ponte Vedra, FL). 
The school is named for Florida conservation and reforestation advocate, 
Allen Dowling Nease (d. 1983), who like Russell Wilson, attended North 
Carolina State Univ. 

More NC State Univ. links: Adriel Johnson (b. 6/22/57; 423-80-8086) earned 
a PhD in animal science/nutritional physiology from the school in 1989. 
Johnson died with fellow faculty member Maria Ragland Davis in the 2/12/10 
Univ. of Alabama-Huntsville shooting. The shooter, biology professor Amy 
Bishop, was reportedly disgruntled because she felt "quota hires" were 
denying her tenure; she used a 9mm handgun in the attack. Davis earned a 
masters in chemical engineering from NC State. Sports teams at the Univ. of 
Alabama-Huntsville are nicknamed Chargers and school colors are royal blue 
and white.﻿

captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
-(SINGING) And this is my wish.

-12-year-old Kevin Lee
of Farmington Hills,

Michigan plays violin in the
orchestra at his middle school.

It's an activity in which
he can participate fully.

More rough and tumble fun
poses a serious threat.

-Because I have this
heart surgery thing.

And it kind of stops
me from doing stuff.

Something could go wrong,
and I could just die.

-It was just moments
after his birth
when doctors whisked Kevin away.

-They found out that
his right ventricle
didn't form when he was born.

And that he was probably
not going to see six months.
The whole world stopped.

My heart just dropped
out of my stomach.
It was terrible.

-Kevin underwent his
first heart surgery
when he was three days old.

He spent his first month
hooked up to a ventilator.
-I just wanted to hold him.

I just wanted to pick
him up and love him.

And I couldn't even
touch my own child.

-What did you say to
him when you held him
for the first time?
-I love you.
And it's going to be OK.

-Kevin's had three
more surgeries

since and some frantic
trips to the ER.

His heart remains susceptible to
a chest impact or overexertion.
-I'm running around and stuff.

And I just stop and
see how it feels.

Sometimes, it feels
like a sword's

going through your
chest or something.

-He's still at a high
risk for sudden death.
So it's every day.
-Kevin's parents are divorced.

His father Doug lives in the
Middle Eastern nation of Qatar,

and returns to
visit once a year.

Sports is a big
part of their bond.

-I think that his
dad not being here,

that this was one thing
that they share is football.

That's something that him and
his dad have always shared.
-Hut!

-Kevin is expecting
a visit this fall.

And being with his dad
is part of his wish,

to meet his favorite player,
Russell Wilson, and the Seattle
Seahawks.

-So if somebody told you
you could have your wish,

I don't know, like tomorrow,
what would you say?

-I would say it's
going to have to wait.

Because I ain't doing
it without my dad here.
-The number 75--

-When Kevin and his extended
family want some Russell Wilson
highlights--

-Are you ignoring me
because football's on?
-Mhmm.

-They're not expecting to
see a message from Coach Pete
Carroll.

-Hey Kevin, this
is Pete Carroll.

I'm the coach at
Seattle Seahawks.

We want to extend an
invitation to you.

I know that you've been battling
and competing like crazy,

and we would love for you to
come out here and visit us.

The Seahawks are practicing,
and you can come and bring
your family with you.

And I want to make sure
you know that we're

going to send you a
little package here.
Good luck.
I'll see you later.
Go Seahawks.
-Did you hear that?

-The coach's invitation leaves
the family ecstatic for Kevin.

But his reaction is
a little bit muted.
-Why are you mad?

Is there a part of your
wish that's missing?
[DOORBELL RINGS]

-Downstairs, hidden behind a
wind blown array of balloons,

is someone who has
traveled some 7,000
miles to be here on this day.
-This is for you.
Hey, buddy.
How you doing?
I love you too, buddy.

-He's been through
more than I'll ever

be through in my
whole entire life.

That's why, to this day,
I call him Superman.
-It's good to see you.
-Let's go Seahawks!

-Days later, Kevin
and family roll up

to the Seahawks
training camp, where
a big time welcome awakes.
-Oh my god.
That's for you.
-With cheerleaders--
-How are you?
Can I get a high five?
-And the Seahawks drum line.

He gets a welcome from Coach
Carroll and GM John Schneider.
-Congratulations, Kevin.
You're part of the Seahawks.

-Who signs Kevin to
a five year deal.

-What do you think of the
contract, first of all?
Do you like it?
-Sort of.

I would like six years, but
you know, if they want five,
they can do that.

-The newest Seahawk
makes a bold prediction.
-I can tell you one thing.
-OK.
-One thing.

There will be a
Super Bowl this year.
-Kevin, Kevin, Kevin, Kevin.

-They're chanting his name
as Kevin makes his way

to the equipment room, smiling,
high fiving, and giving
autographs.
-You're so cool, Kevin.
-There we go.

-He gets a helmet,
and his ankles taped.
-Are you fast?
-Yes.
-Yeah.
I could tell.
That's why I used the fast tape.

-Kevin and his dad check
out practice for a bit.
Here comes Russell Wilson.
-What's up, Bud?
How you doing, man?
Nice jersey you got on.
-Thanks.
-Come on, come with me.
I'll show you something cool.
Keep them eyes closed.
You ready?
Open your eyes.
-Whoa.
-You got your own locker, man.
What you think?

-After posing for
photos, these two

head off to lunch, where
Kevin's come prepared

with a notebook full of
interesting questions

for Russell and
receiver Golden Tate.
-I do hate losing.

That is one thing
I very much hate.

Can you give me any advice on
how to handle it and stuff?

-I think the biggest
thing about losing

is being humble about it, not
being a sore loser in terms

of trying to learn from
my wins, and trying
to learn from my losses.

-I'd say the biggest thing
is just don't show it.
Be strong about it.

Try to come back and have your
best week of practice ever.

-On the way back to practice,
All-Pro cornerback Richard
Sherman gets Kevin fired up.
-You ready, Kevin?
-Sure.

-See, no, that's
not enthusiastic.

Are you ready to
tell [INAUDIBLE]?
-Yeah!
-That's what I'm talking about.

-As the players take
the field, Kevin

joins them for stretching
and some drills.
-Pick your feet up. [INAUDIBLE].

Put your hands behind
your head, like this.
There it is.
-Go a little back and see.
There you go.

-Pete Carroll checks out
his new player's potential.

Finally, the boy who
doesn't always get to play

back home takes the field
here with Russell Wilson,

and shows off his
quarterback arm.
-Nice throw.
-Hut!

-If you run up five
yards and run out,
look around the out route.

And then go up, right in
between the two of them, OK?
-It's a touchdown.

And his touchdown dance
gets the whole team going.
-Good to see you, buddy.
See you, buddy.
I'll see you, OK?

-On his way out,
Kevin sees his name

on the Seahawks All
Time roster, a fitting
ending to his special day.

title: My Wish: Seattle Seahawks Grant Kevin Lee's Wish
